title: 104_s1341
content: The Act titled "Saddleback Mountain-Arizona Settlement Act of 1995" is established for specific purposes. The Saddleback Property, located in Scottsdale, Arizona, holds conservation value and cultural significance for the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community. Acquired by the Resolution Trust Corporation in 1989, a dispute arose over its sale. The Resolution Trust Corporation mediated a dispute between the Community and the City regarding the future ownership and development of the Saddleback Property. Both parties agreed to a Settlement Agreement, where the Community will purchase a portion of the property and the City will purchase the remaining portion, leading to the dismissal of litigation. The Settlement Agreement between the Community and the City requires Congressional ratification for it to become effective and for the United States to take the property into trust. The purposes of the Act are to approve the Settlement Agreement and ensure its enforcement. The Settlement Agreement between the Community and the City requires Congressional ratification for it to become effective and for the United States to take the property into trust. The Act aims to approve the Settlement Agreement and ensure its enforcement, including judicial remedies and binding arbitration provisions. It also involves the taking into trust of the portion of the Saddleback Property purchased by the Community to make it part of the Reservation. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this Act, definitions include City as Scottsdale, Arizona, Community as Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community, Dedication Property as part of Saddleback Property, and Development Agreement as the agreement between City and Community. The Property Conveyance Agreement applies to the future use and development of the Development Property, Mountain Property, and Preservation Property as part of the Saddleback Property. The Reservation refers to the Salt River. The terms defined in this section include Reservation (Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Reservation), Saddleback Property (701 acres in Scottsdale, Arizona), Secretary (Secretary of the Interior), and Settlement Agreement (agreement executed in 1995). The Use Agreement, part of the Settlement Agreement, outlines conditions for future use of the Mountain Property. The Settlement Agreement is approved and ratified, enforceable according to its terms and this Act. Properties will be transferred as outlined in the agreement. Upon satisfaction of all conditions in the Settlement Agreement, the Resolution Trust Corporation will transfer properties to the Secretary and the City. The Mountain Property and Development Property will be held in trust by the United States for the Community and become part of the Reservation. The United States will not incur liability for conditions. Upon satisfaction of all conditions in the Settlement Agreement, the Secretary will file a plat of survey depicting the Saddleback Property with the Recorder of Maricopa County, Arizona, and the Titles and Records Center of the Bureau of Indian Affairs in New Mexico. The United States will not incur liability for pre-existing conditions on the land to be transferred to the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS ON USE AND DEVELOPMENT. The properties transferred under the Settlement Agreement shall be preserved as a public park or recreation area, subject to specific restrictions and conditions. A portion of the Preservation Property may be used to widen Shea Boulevard at the City's discretion. The Preservation Property can be used to widen, reconfigure, repair, or reengineer Shea Boulevard and 136th Street. The Mountain Property, except for Special Cultural Land areas, will be preserved as a public park or recreation area with specific restrictions. The Development Property must be used for the economic benefit of the Community as outlined in the Settlement Agreement. No amendment to the Settlement Agreement shall be effective unless it complies with the approval requirements and is consistent with the provisions of this Act.
